post.description:
authenticates a given account. Two authentication methods are supported: local and shibboleth:
  • local: the account authenticates using a local account (via credentials). You can choose if session_token and app_token are saved as cookies.
  • shibboleth: the account authenticates via Shibboleth (the shibboleth authentication must be supported by the server). session_token and app_token are saved as cookies.

usernameOrEmail.description: You can set this value with either a username or an email address.

useCookies.description: Defines if app token and session token should be saved as cookies.

info.title: OCTRA API
info.description:
# Introduction The OCTRA-API is a REST-API that allows apps to interact with the OCTRA Database (OCTRA-DB) and its project files. In order to use this API you should meet the following requirements: 1. You have a valid app token. You can request an app token from the administrator (contact octra@phonetik.uni-muenchen.de).
The app token should be sent... a. ... with each HTTP-Request in a HTTP-header called "X-App-Token". For example:
X-App-Token: 7328z4093u492u4902u348

App tokens are bound to specific domains (aka "origins").
b. ... or with each HTTP-Request as cookie "ocb_app_token" (added by the server automatically). This method is recommended for web applications. c. ... or with each HTTP-Request as query parameter "app_token" (only recommended for HTML embedded files if cookies can't be used). 2. All HTTP-requests but the authentication methods need the user to be authenticated. The OCTRA-API uses JWT (Jason Web Token) for authentication and authorization. A successful login request returns the JWT which is valid for 24h. This JWT must be appended ... a. ... to the "Authorization" HTTP-Header. For example: Authorization: Bearer 7328z40293i8403429302934 b. ... or as cookie called "ocb_sessiontoken". You need this e.g. if you want the user to access embedded files in HTML. c. ... or with each HTTP-Request as query parameter "session_token" (only recommended for HTML embedded files if cookies can't be used). **Notice:** If you call API methods via terminal you can't use cookies and have to add the tokens to the headers or query parameters. If you have to retrieve files from a project programmatically you can add the app and session tokens as query parameters. ## Role model This API makes use of a role model. Each user has exactly one global role and project-specific roles. ### Global roles
administrator System administrator with full access to all API functions.
user Default role for users with normal access rights.
app Role for Desktop-applications. See notice below.
#### Notice about app roles
Applications need to be authenticated like normal users but without the need of accepting the data policy and terms & conditions. The owner of the app has to make sure that our policies are accepted by users whose data is shared with octra-backend.
### Project-specific roles
project_admin Project administrator with administrative access rights for the project he or she is assigned with.
data_delivery Data deliverer with limited access rights.
There are custom roles that are created by the administrator. As long as an API method allow role "user" a user with a custom role is allows to call this method.
## About OCBJSONFileReference OCB uses the IO pattern, that means that each task processes inputs to outputs. Both, inputs and outputs are uploaded as files, even when changing tasks. To represent existing IO as file we developed a JSON structure: ````json type!: 'ocb-file'; version!: string; // task_input_output_id. If set it means that a given task_input_output should be changed id?: string; // either file.id, file.url or file.hash must exist file?: { // project_file_id. If id and file.id set it means that project_file of a given task_io with id should be changed to file.id id?: string; // <- project_file_id // if no ids set, create new project_file with given data if it doesn exist url?: string; filename?: string; hash?: string; path?: string; metaData?: OCBAudioFileMetaData; content?: string; file_type?: string; content_type?: string; size?: number; }; ```` That allows developers to control the changing mechanism of IOs: If `id` is set to id x it tells OCB to use IO with id x. Further more, if `file.id` is set to y, it tells OCB to use file_project with id y. If you add more attributes to `file` OCB checks if file_project needs to be updated. If you don't set `id` it tells OCB to create a new IO with the other data applied in this JSON. If you don't set `file.id` it tells OCB to (additionally) create a new file_project with given data. As you can see, you can manipulate this JSON as you wish.

id.description: Primary, unique identifier for this entry

registrations.description: defines that this app may use registerAccount() function

reset_password.description: defines that this app may use resetPassword() function

authentications.description: defines the valid authentication methods for this app. Default: all supported methods

shutdown.description: defines that this app may use shutdownSystem() function

send_feedback.description: defines that this app may use the sendFeedback() function

id.description: Primary, unique identifier for this entry

projectRoles.description: user roles of this account associated to specific projects.

last_login.description:
date on that this account logged in.
@example: 2022-09-12T12:00.000Z

openURL.description: if the authentication method is shibboleth, this URL directs to the confirmShibboleth page. If there are pending agreements, this URL directs to the agreement page. Undefined otherwise.

accessToken.description: this token exists if the authentication was successful (correct credentials & no pending agreements).

agreementToken.description: this token exists if there are any policies the user has to agree with. `openURL` will direct to an agreement page. The duration of this token is set to 1 hour. This token can only be used on the agreement page.

me.description: this property only exists if the authentication was successful.

active.description: describes if the account is active.

projectRoles.description: user roles of this account associated to specific projects.

last_login.description:
date on that this account logged in.
@example: 2022-09-12T12:00.000Z
